title: For any seven consecutive day period between 1 October and 31 December 2020, will there be 200,000 or more combined total confirmed new cases of COVID-19 in the United States?
preds: Sadly, Walensky was right... https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1074426 Four days into October, and it's almost certain that 200,000 infections will be surpassed after five days of reports already.

According to the WHO dashboard, there have already been 129,754 cases in the US from 1 Oct to 3 Oct. Only 70,246 cases need to be reported in the next four days (this is guaranteed barring some weird data reporting fudging) for this to resolve positively. And it's only the first week of October!
Current daily infection rates are about 40k new cases per and would easily exceed 200k in a seven day period.

new combined total confirmed cases in the last 7 days is 305,412, and it looks like new cases has plateaued - not expecting much change from that for next week. That puts the chance at very close to 100% for the three month period, let alone the first week of the three month period.

Heading into October, the 7-day average for cases is 42,447 cases/day. At this rate, we would AVERAGE well over 200,000 cases each week (97,127 more to be exact). Cases would need to drop by nearly 33% in the next week for this benchmark to not be hit immediately, let alone in the 3 month period allowed here. While case counts are volatile, the current trend appears to be slightly upward, not downward, and such a drop was not observed even at the peak of shutdown measures. With many states reopening and people growing bored with many of the safety measures dictated by the CDC, this is essentially a layup at this point.

Current estimate with 100% certainty: this question will be resolved on 8 October, as confirmed new cases data for days prior to 1 October 2020 are immaterial to the resolution of this question. 1-7 October will be far above 200K.

Feeling like an outlier, but here goes... As many others have pointed out, daily confirmed cases are a simple function of (#_DAILY_TESTS x %_POSITIVE). I looked at a simple Monte Carlo with following values for those inputs: -Range of .75-1.75MM #_DAILY_TESTS // This seems conservative for the subject timeframe, vis-a-vis current projections on required testing for broad reopening. [1]
-Range of 1.5-4 %_POSITIVE // This also feels conservative, given that the current trend appears to be starting to level around 5% positive, even as testing substantially increases. It seems reasonable that %_POSITIVE will stay closer to 5% than 0, to the extent that several studies have estimated that we have been under reporting ~90% of cases. [2] With these parameters, approximately 94% of seven-day totals are >= 200,000. I feel pretty solid in the foregoing logic, but adjust down by 15% for a whole host of reasons, among them the potential for: -Issues with scaling of testing (seems to be going pretty well so far)
-Reopening going extremely well (fairly confident there will be hiccups)
-Extreme pressure felt by Trump admin to minimize deaths/spread as election approaches (they’ll feel the pressure, but we’ll see what they can/will do about that)
-I’m a little scared to be so far off from the crowd on this one :-) If #_DAILY_TESTS continues to climb without hitting much resistance, and the decay on %_POSITIVE is minimal, I will continue to adjust upward toward the straight output of the Monte Carlo. [1] https://www.kff.org/coronavirus-policy-watch/what-testing-capacity-do-we-need/
[2] https://www.medrxiv.org/content/10.1101/2020.04.29.20083485v1

ticking up one percentage point as things move in an unfavorable direction, but my reasoning is the same as my previous estimate. I suspect this is very likely (94%):
# seasonality may have somewhat slowed the spread of covid in the US during the summer months
# there are still many pockets of largely unaffected communities ripe for outbreaks
# many states seem to be happy to maintain a relatively large outbreak as long as it doesn't overwhelm their health systems
# schools will likely increase transmission rates after a few weeks of in person sessions
# rollbacks of reopenings are going to very difficult politically
# some people who were initially infected at the beginning of the year could be vulnerable to reinfection
# better testing picks up more cases the reasons I can think of that this might not happen (6%):
# the broader population takes the threat seriously and shifts behavior interrupting transmission chains in an unexpected way
# better methods of testing and contact tracing lead to more effective controls
# maybe more people have already had the virus than originally anticipated AND time to when reinfection is possible is long enough to slow transmission

Down to 95 again for this reason: 
"DSHS revised its method for reporting Total Tests, effective 9/14/2020. DSHS will now only report electronic lab results that have passed quality checks and have cleared into the state’s system of record, NEDSS, the National Electronic Disease Surveillance System. This improvement is possible due to recent upgrades to NEDSS, which now processes data more quickly. The revised methodology ensures data is fully deduplicated and that only tests that passed through the data submission quality checks are counted in Total Tests. Test submissions that error out of the system due to data quality issues will not be counted until they are successfully resubmitted and pass validation requirements. Additionally, Total Tests will no longer include faxes or aggregate counts received by various labs since there is not a timely way to complete data quality checks. "

Children are returning to school en masse, several large gatherings have occurred in recent weeks that drew attendees from around the country, and testing of asymptomatic people has been dismissed by the CDC. With all this in mind, I believe it is more likely the cases will increase than decrease at least for a time. A previous Monte Carlo simulation assuming an average around 40,000 put the likelihood of a single week greater than 200,000 is around 90%, I think it is slightly less likely now than then but I see no reason to decrease my projection by a significant amount.

New update, this time I will try to moderate my estimations downwards. As usual, I use a week-vs-week exponential model, from which I relate the number of new weekly cases as: Cases(day_n) - Cases(day_n - 7) = x * (Cases(day_n - 7) - Cases(day_n - 14)) right now we have somewhere between 300-330K cases per week (307K as of yesterday, but the latest number can always be a statistical fluke) and for x we have the following values: x (last 7 days) = 0.898 +/- 0.058
x (last 14 days) = 0.910 +/- 0.052 
x (last 21 days) = 0.902 +/- 0.047 which, despite the marked decreased of x in the last few 3 days or so, are remarkably consistent numbers. Now lets argue: 1) If we want to avoid having 200K cases on the first week of October, we need x < 0.937, which is within a 1 sigma error band of the numbers I have given above. Depending on where I do begin for number of weekly cases, I get a 22-33% probability that this question will be closed the 7th of October (if I reduced the variance owing to the fact that I have to combine exponentials, I will get 4-12% of closing during the first week). 2) But the previous assumes that x is going to be maintained at the current level for about 39 days (or 39+7 days), give or take. And here a problem arises. So far for the US the longest streak with x < 1.0 has been 32 days, and the current streak is already 25 days long. That is, we need 64 days of x < 1.0 (actually of x around 0.937, which is more stringent than the previous condition) to avoid hitting the 200K mark on the first week of October. If we assume that the probability of x < 1 is independent of what has happened in the past, there is at least a 50% probability (minimum) that this does not hold till the 1st of October. But it could be higher. 3) Combining 1 and 2, I will end with somewhere between 60 and 65% that the question ends in the first week of October, which does not look particularly good. However, the end date of the question is not the 7th of October, but 31st of December. How much this raises the probability? Well, I do not know, but probably significantly. There is also the longer view coming from Europe and other countries with a second wave: in a time frame of 3 to 6 months, the probabilities of getting more cases than during the first wave are significant (but I did not outside-view them, sorry. Anyone wanting to analyze second waves in terms of time frames and sizes, @pstamp @juancambeiro @Dillyweed @jainsa @Leonardthethird @tccoleman26 @A356 ?). 4) But as a matter of fact, there might be factors pushing the probability both up and down: 4.a) Up: the kids are back to school, people are back to work
4.b) Down: the current wave has affected mostly young people trying to have fun. This ends in September. Besides, this time social distancing might finally be taken seriously. Frankly, I find the arguments for "Up" more convincing than for "Down". For the moment I will settle on 91%, and then I will try to outside-view the second waves in a series of countries to pin down the probabilities in the medium to long run.

Assuming there is no (1) coordinated national action; (2) vaccine; and (3) complete lockdown; and adding in (a) school; (b) tiring of lockdown and masks, it seems to me like it is very likely that there are going to be continued cases. Mask use during COVID-19: A risk adjusted strategy*
-
Wang, Pan, Tang, Ji and Shi (2020) June 25, stated that:
-
In the past two decades, countries in East Asia have experienced infectious disease epidemics or air pollution episodes, such as Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS), avian influenza, influenza, and haze events. Hence, wearing masks has become a pervasive in society as a way to prevent exposure. This is for good reason, as the population density in Asian countries is generally higher than that in western countries, and the crowding in a confined place will increase the infection risk or exposure. Therefore, during the COVID-19 pandemic, the public is encouraged to wear masks in public places and people often comply as a form of health-seeking behavior (Greenhalgh et al., 2020) (Para. 7).
However, in many western advanced economies, those wearing masks are often met with suspicion in public, even causing panic in certain situation. Universal mask use in the community has been discouraged by some health authorities with the argument that masks provide no effective protection against coronavirus infection (Feng et al., 2020). Although the 1918 Pandemic (H1N1 virus) caused an estimated 40–50 million deaths worldwide, many still may view personal protective equipment (PPE) and physical barrier including wearing the mask as contrary to freedom and individualism (World Health Organization, 2005). Furthermore, there are some cultural underpinning of the use of masks as well, as it was partially prohibited by the introduction of no mask act under the background of increasing political demonstration and terrorist attacks. Since the transmission route of SARS-CoV-2 has not been fully understood, thus wearing masks should indeed be a cautionary prevention course of action (Para. 8). 2.2. The effectiveness of the mask
As a basic non-pharmaceutical intervention (NPI) measure, wearing a mask is an effective means of preventing respiratory infectious diseases, which could reduce the risk of infection (World Health Organization Writing Group, 2006). In this study, mask is defined as a device covering the mouth and nose providing a barrier to minimize the direct transmission of infective agents according to relevant standards, including disposable medical mask, surgical mask, and respirator with or without valve, etc. (British Standards Institution, 2019; Standardization administration of China, 2016). In a large systematic review of physical interventions to control spread of infectious diseases, Jefferson et al. concluded from 67 studies that wearing masks is effective as one of the important barriers to transmission of respiratory viruses, and evidences indicate N95 respirators were non-inferior to surgical masks (Jefferson et al., 2011). Other studies also found evidence that wearing masks can significantly reduce the risk of SARS and influenza-related diseases (Jefferson et al., 2009; Macintyre et al., 2009; Zhang et al., 2013). Aldila et al. constructed MERS determinant mathematical model and found that compared with auxiliary nursing and government publicity, wearing masks is the optimal choice for reducing the number of infections (Aldila et al., 2018). In addition, the costs of wearing masks is also the lowest for society, as it is a simple low-cost intervention (Aldila et al., 2018). During SARS epidemic, a survey conducted in the United States, Singapore, Chinese Taiwan, and Hong Kong showed that the meaning of wearing masks has exceeded their direct effects in disease prevention and has become a means of raising public awareness of other NPIs, such as isolation (Pillemer et al., 2015). Barasheed et al. systematically analyzed the utilization and effectiveness of masks by integrating 12,710 samples from more than 50 countries in the world, and found that wearing masks in crowded places could reduce the risk of respiratory infections by 20% (Barasheed et al., 2016). A study in Hong Kong found that the odds ratio (OR) value of wearing masks in public places was only 0.36, which was lower than that of living room disinfection (OR = 0.41) and frequent hand washing (OR = 0.58), indicating that wearing masks effectively restricted the community spread of SARS-CoV in Hong Kong (Lau et al., 2004) (Para 10).
-
Reference
-

The average number of reported infections in a seven day time frame in the US between April 1, 2020 and today, July 14th was 208,447 according to NY Times data. The standard deviation of this data is 69,000, indicating that there has been great range. However, on only 42% of days during this time frame was the sum of the previous seven days infection totals greater than 200,000. In the past seven days however, 421,759 infections were reported. Recently, this has been trending upwards, and totals in the near future are expected to increase/ Furthermore, the US gross testing rates today (and even more so from April 1 until now) have been very low. I mentioned this in another question, but I think its relevant here too: According to the NY Times, 34/50 states are below the standard testing threshold determined by the Harvard Global Health Institute. Nationwide, 690,000 tests are being conducted each day. The goal is ~2,000,000 daily tests. The US is currently testing only at ~35% of its target figure each day. Under-testing in the US not only accelerates the spread of the virus due to poor detection of cases, it will result in higher reported figures in later months when testing is ramped up. The country is currently reopening, and combined with increased testing, infection rates will increase. Although infection rates in populous states are currently extremely high, as testing increases, more infections will be reported. Furthermore, in the final three months of the year the weather gets colder, which will move people inside and further viral spread. Thanksgiving and the holiday season are heavy travel holidays, which can definitely spread the virus further.  A better way to frame this probability is to look at the odds of the US having fewer than 200,000 infections for all seven consecutive day time frames this fall. This would mean the US more than halving the current infection rates, even as school and universities reopen, the country reopens and testing becomes more prevalent. Because of all of this, I think there is an 80% chance of a having at least one seven day period with more than 200,000 reported infections this fall, which is roughly twice the base rate of 42% given from historic data since April 1st, though takes into account the great uncertainties around COVID-19 infection data.

After making my previous forecast this morning i decided to take the time and update my not very fancy spreadsheet as i haven't gotten around to it this week.  Here's what my spreadsheet (using numbers from covidtracking.com) tells me: 10, 30, 90 daily average new tests: 545k / 490k / 327k
10, 30, 90 daily positive:  34k / 26k / 26k
10, 30, 90 daily avg share positive:  6.3% / 5.2% / 10.4%
10, 30, 90 daily average  day over day test growth:  2.6% / 1.9% / 3.8% To me what's most interesting is share positive appears to be increasing even as tests are also increasing.  This is significant because I think tests will only continue to rise and I believe the true number of daily new cases is larger than what tests have previously captured.  Of course, there are multiple world's where we reach the 200k+ 7 day case count in specified time frame  We can imagine one world where share positive continues to drop, but tests increase substantially enough that we hit 200k (daily share positive 1%, daily tests 3M+).  We can also imagine a world where both tests and share positive increases and we hit 200k+.  We can also imagine a world where tests decrease due to a shortage but share positive increases so much that we hit 200k+ (30% share positive, 100k daily tests) .   Now, as far as I can tell, the lowest daily share positive was around 3.98% on Monday, June 1st 2020, which is 23,880 daily new cases if we assume 600k daily tests. As many others have pointed out, daily confirmed cases are a simple function of (#_DAILY_TESTS x %_POSITIVE). [1]
-Range of 1.5-4 %_POSITIVE // This also feels conservative, given that the current trend appears to be starting to level around 5% positive, even as testing substantially increases. It seems reasonable that %_POSITIVE will stay closer to 5% than 0, to the extent that several studies have estimated that we have been under reporting ~90% of cases. [2] With these parameters, approximately 94% of seven-day totals are >= 200,000. The second wave is likely to peak before October, several factors are likely to reduce the peak in fall but have a more sustained plateau.

-If U.S. as a whole has a peak of new daily cases as high or higher than its first peak in the time period 1 Oct to 31 Dec, then the answer to this question is "yes".
-As of today (16 June) we seem to headed towards a new peak.
-There is great resistance to renewed "lockdown measures" in states experiencing rising cases.
-We are at over 2K daily new cases in AR, TX, and FL. This is likely to rise even if those states impose new lockdowns, since new cases go back around 2-3 weeks from point of infection.
-U.S. seems to dealing with this at the state level and unlikely that will change. U.S. will likely not try to impose restrictions in states that are contributing heavily to the national total, for structural (state autonomy) and political reasons.
-A second peak is likely prior to 1 Oct, which will lead to public pressure for renewed lockdowns, and the lockdowns will come but much later than if we had a centralized system like China.
-(Outcome of U.S. election on 8 Nov is unlikely to affect this dynamic.)
-Thus I believe that second peak is coming, and it can be equal to or higher than the first, but it will come sooner than 1 Oct.
-There will be pressure to keep schools closed during a renewed 2-3 month lockdown period.
-These factors suggest that only if we have a *third* ramp up period and peak between 1 Oct and 31 Dec, can the question have a "yes" answer.
-Uptick to next uptick was about three months. If pattern repeats, uptick of third wave will be about mid Sept.
-So, will this third uptick, assuming it happens in mid Sept., lead to a peak as high as the first?
-Looking at 1918 city-by-city stats, no city has this pattern of a third peak (if there is one) as high as the first. (A handful have second peaks as high or higher that first.)
-As of today, it seems that curve-flattening factors will outweigh those that contribute to high peaks, just prior to the time period, keeping any third peak lower than the first.

Feeling like an outlier, but here goes... As many others have pointed out, daily confirmed cases are a simple function of (#_DAILY_TESTS x %_POSITIVE).  I looked at a simple Monte Carlo with following values for those inputs: -Range of .75-1.75MM #_DAILY_TESTS // This seems conservative for the subject timeframe, vis-a-vis current projections on required testing for broad reopening. [1]
-Range of 1.5-4 %_POSITIVE // This also feels conservative, given that the current trend appears to be starting to level around 5% positive, even as testing substantially increases. It seems reasonable that %_POSITIVE will stay closer to 5% than 0, to the extent that several studies have estimated that we have been under reporting ~90% of cases. [2]  With these parameters, approximately 94% of seven-day totals are >= 200,000. I feel pretty solid in the foregoing logic, but adjust down by 15% for a whole host of reasons, among them the potential for: -Issues with scaling of testing (seems to be going pretty well so far)
-Reopening going extremely well (fairly confident there will be hiccups)
-Extreme pressure felt by Trump admin to minimize deaths/spread as election approaches (they’ll feel the pressure, but we’ll see what they can/will do about that)
-I’m a little scared to be so far off from the crowd on this one  :-) If #_DAILY_TESTS continues to climb without hitting much resistance, and the decay on %_POSITIVE is minimal, I will continue to adjust upward toward the straight output of the Monte Carlo. [1] https://www.kff.org/coronavirus-policy-watch/what-testing-capacity-do-we-need/
[2] https://www.medrxiv.org/content/10.1101/2020.04.29.20083485v1

If the virus sticks around until the fall, or goes away and comes back, the question comes down to several factors.  IMHO the most important factors for purposes of this question are: 1) Will we be better prepared for the second wave that we were for the first wave?  My assumption is that we will be better prepared, although our incompetence to date does allow for the possibility that we will not.  If we are prepared to do massive testing, tracing and isolation we could limit the spread to well under the levels of April.  Even if we only do half as well as Taiwan or New Zealand we could severely limit the spread of new cases. 2) If there is another outbreak in the fall will we be prepared to go into lockdown again.  I believe the answer to this is a definite NO.  And if we do sufficient testing and tracing we should not need to have another lockdown.  Will the authorities foresee the possibility a the second wave AND prepare for it?  Or will we again take the ostrich approach and just wish it away?  I do not believe we will make the same mistake twice, but there will of course be new mistakes to make. 3) Will there be a significantly more dangerous mutation by October/November, one that is more transmissible?  I have no idea.  But again, if we are prepared to quickly isolate the virus, develop a test, and ramp up test capacity quickly we should be able to limit the spread. The crowd is at 38% at this time.  I will start with a guess of 23%.  The summer months will be crucial preparation time, so we will have to watch what is happening during the political "silly season" to get a better handle on how this will play out.

Current confirmed cases in 7-day period appears to have peaked on 12th April at ~217k and has now dropped back below 200k. It appears very unlikely that with the current testing regime the current wave will lead to the >200k confirmed cases at the end of this year. Hence, as many have said, this depends on the likelihood of, and potential impact of, a second wave in the Winter. These factors depend on (among other things) the spread of the first wave and implication if reinfection can / cannot occur with the same (or a suitably similar) strain, the likelihood of mutation that could cause a new outbreak and potential severity of mutated strain (R, fatality rate, etc), impact of winter weather on the disease, number of (and methodology for) testing being conducted at the time, etc. There are lots to consider, making a sensible prediction difficult. Taking the current number of confirmed deaths (36k), an estimate of the IFR at ~0.5-1.0% and a mean time from infection to death of ~20 days, this yields approximately 3.6-7.2m infections in the US as of 20 days ago and playing that forward at the rate of increase in confirmed cases, ~16-32m infections today. A long tailed (slow decline in the number of infections) simulation would give ~50-100m infections total in this "wave" (or ~15-30% of the total population). If reinfection is assumed to not be on the cards, this would still be a large enough population for a major outbreak to occur again with the same strain of the virus (especially considering a heterogeneous population - there may be pockets where there is localised "herd immunity" such as NY and NJ but other areas with limited immunity). Hence a second wave (potentially exacerbated by weather) could potentially emerge under the same strain. Likelihood of mutation that  is something that I am not well versed on, though reading suggests that the virus is mutating slowly and most mutations are benign. Most important is whether mutations negate any natural (potential) antibody resistance preventing reinfection as this would effectively reset the clock and increase the likelihood of a similar second wave spike. Testing would seem unlikely to be a limiter in reaching the specified number of weekly cases as capacity has ramped up already (and could be switched back on if required) and the period is long enough to allow a repeated ramp up if required. All-in-all, definitely a possibility but too early to make anything more than an educated stab in the dark. Sources: 
Lower limit on IFR (0.5%) using data from Iceland (12% population tested with IFR of ~0.5%) (https://www.covid.is/data)
Mean time from infection to death (https://www.nature.com/articles/s41591-020-0822-7)

Does anyone have thoughts on how to model / predict the possibility of a mutation? My impression from reading papers is that the models everyone talks about seem to generally not attempt to model the possibility of major mutations. Instead they treat mutation from a scenario planning approach and mostly ignore it from what I can see. Here's a rough shot at estimating an outside view on the question:  I just read through wikipedia on the largest viral epidemics since 1900. There are too many to deal with and most are too small to be useful for this purpose), but I focused on the ones that were largest (>100M infected) and most deadly (>100k deaths) were: 
     -- 1918 "Spanish Flu" / Influenza A virus subtype H1N1
     -- 1957 "Asian Flu" / Influenza A virus subtype H2N2
     -- 1968 "Hong Kong Flu" / Influenza A virus subtype H3N2
     -- 2009 "Swine Flu" / Pandemic H1N1/09 virus (kind of different that the ones above. Much lower mortality rate) I recognize that none of these are coronaviruses and are therefore of uncertain use as models for constructing an outside view on COVID-19. Still, it's the data we have so... In 3 of the 4 flu cases (Swine flu being the exception), there was apparently mutation that lead to second waves that differed from the original in terms of a) demographics affected, b) more contagious; c) higher mortality rate. In 3 of 4 cases the second (and subsequent in a couple of cases) waves were bigger than the first. In 4 of 4 cases the timing of the 2nd wave was in the fall/winter following the initial wave, although one didn't start until January.  By comparison, almost all of the smaller epidemics I glanced at (10-15 viral epidemics) didn't seem to show evidence of a significant mutation which makes sense because the likelihood of mutation is proportional to the number of people infected. Those were generally in the thousands or tens of thousands. (Note that many had an initial mutation that brought them into existence and some had many small mutations which didn't change their character; neither of  which I'm counting.)  My conclusions are: 
1) in no case was the mutated version completely different than the first. They were just slightly nastier, slightly more contagious versions of the already nasty original
2)  the probability of mutation seems to be real. Maybe 50-75%
3) The probability of mutation should be roughly proportional to he number of people infected. So if you say that at >100M infected the probability of significant mutation is ~75%; and at <100k infected the probability is low, like say ~1%, that implies that COVID with 10-20M people infected (??) we are probably around ~20-25%?  Epidemiologists seem to think that risk of mutation is highest in places were there is a high degree of chaos and danger, like in war zones. The reason is apparently that evolutionary forces in normal civilian environments leads to lower mortality because people who get sick are quarantined. However, this is apparently less true or even reversed in very harsh situations like war, refugee camps or extreme poverty: even very sick people can't be quarantined effectively so higher severity mutations can spread. Curious if others have thoughts (or links to sources) on how to estimate an outside view on the possibility of mutation and how that might affect the odds on this question . This is a tough one for the following reasons.  The likely scenario wrt mitigation efforts is that they will be moderately effective. Right now, on April 18 we are getting roughly 30,000 new cases a day.  Given the current testing problem in the US, that is surely a severe under count.  Let's suppose it is off by an order of magnitude, and we have 300,000 new cases a day.  Since some of the 30,000 cases per day self-present and are not picked up by testing, that suggests many cases with moderate symptoms.  Those with mild symptoms self-quarantine and/or do not infect people now given the lockdown.  Some people we know have no symptoms and would only get identified if they were randomly tested.  So, suppose we now have 300,000 cases per day, or 2.1 million per week.  If that is the case, it really depends on whether we are testing enough people in the Fall of 2021.  I think testing will increase, not because the Federal government wants more testing, but because there will be demand for testing and antibody testing that will increase the test supply.  If we have sufficient testing, I think we could have a 7 day period with over 300,000 cases.  My analysis suggests there will be that many new cases, but my uncertainty is whether there will be that many tests.

If we loosen up by June and July and cases spike up to a second surge we might be back in lockdown by then. The testing should be better so hopefully if people are out and about we can manage the infection rate better. Who knows?

Nothing is impossible but I assume that people will be cautious and conscious enough to follow the appropriate measures by then (distancing, wearing masks, hygiene). This concerns in particular those that work in jobs that are the most in danger to get an infection. In addition, I imagine there will be strict measures put in place by the authorities as soon as an infected case is registered. I'll have to adjust for the case that people tested by antibody tests are counted in as well.

Increasing the estimate I just gave of 5%. I forgot to account for the fact that increased testing means that the virus doesn't have to get as bad as it is now to reach a similar number of confirmed cases.

The current lockdown is expected to last until mid-May in most states. It may be extended again, but I expect most businesses to be open again by the end of June. There could be a second wave of infections as the economy opens again, but I expect it to be detected quickly, because our testing is significantly better now. So the second wave would peak by August at the latest. I could be wrong if all of the following events happen:
- A second wave occurs.
- A significant fraction of the country decides that the threat from coronavirus was overblown, and refuses to respect official lockdown orders again.
- The virus then spreads even faster and further than before. I find this alternative scenario unlikely. 81% of the US agrees that social distancing should continue, even if it damages the economy (https://thehill.com/homenews/news/492886-poll-81-percent-say-keep-social-distancing-despite-damage-to-economy). And I expect this to be true especially in the largest cities, which (a) are most susceptible, and have been hit the hardest by the virus, and (b) tend to be more Democratic, which also correlates with taking the virus seriously.
Not enough evidence government systems, either local or federal, have learned enough from the present crisis as to prepare properly to curtail a second one.
